transcripts.text: Can I say something?
No, you are not enslaved, so it's not your history.
No, I said descendants of those people.
Why do you people all identify with all black people?
Jesus Christ.
I don't know why you're calling his name.  You don't identify with him.
Yeah, I identify with that black Messiah.  I sure do.
See there?  That's what it's like.
Let me say this.
This is why you're blind and can't see.  Okay.  Let me go to Thomas out of Michigan.  Thomas, thank you for calling and thanks for holding.  You're on the air.
Good morning, Jesse.
Hey, Thomas.  How are you, sir?  All is well.  How are you?
I'm good.
No man is good.
I'm fine.  I'm wonderful.  I'm terrific.  I'm okay.  So listen, I heard you say recently that White History Month is coming up.
That's right.  White History Month.

And I don't have any issues with white folks celebrating history or anybody.  But my thing is, I've heard you say before that we shouldn't be into our blackness.  And we don't need Black History Month.  So is it bad for me to celebrate being black?
Come back to the phone.

I mean, not black, but being African.  Yeah.  My culture, my heritage, because my white friends, they celebrate being Italian or Irish, Polish.  My Jewish friends, they got holidays and all that.  What do I have?  Why can't I celebrate my roots without being a militant or radical?

Because most black people are militants, radical, angry people.  That's why they're suffering, and that's why they can't get ahead, because they're in a fallen state.  Satan is their daddy.  And, well, the reason I started White History Month—and, by the way, July is White History Month, for those who don't know—is because they're celebrating everything else but white history.  And they have— Mother's Day, Father's Day, homosexuals.  The whole month of June is dedicated to homosexuals.  Can you imagine that?  And then they have Black History Month.  They have Mexican history.  Everything but white history.  And if it wasn't for white people, there would be no America.  And so whenever they do mention white history or white people, it's in a negative way.  And if we allow that to continue, we are going to lose America completely.  We have to have some appreciation for the folks who made it possible for us to be in America.
Well, what about for the folks who built it on their backs for free labor?
No one did that.  What about my ancestors?  That didn't happen.  They got paid.
We didn't get paid in slavery.
Yes, you did.  That's not true.
Wait a minute.  So you said we worked from slavery $250,000.
Did you work slavery when you were enslaved?
No, I'm saying my ancestors.
When you said we, you sound like you were enslaved.
Your ancestors and mine.

No, mine didn't work slavery.  And no slave worked for free.  That's a lie.  They got money.  They got houses.  They were taken care of.  They were fed.  They were fed.  Yeah.  They got free houses.  Well, not free houses.  They worked and earned for their shelter.
Oh, my God.  Jesse, come on.

Wait a minute.  When you say come on, are you saying that they did not get houses?  They were not living in houses and things like that?  No, Thomas, Thomas, Thomas, Thomas.  Were the slaves living in slave quarters?  But were they living in them?  Thomas, were they living in them?  And did they have to pay for it?  Wait, stay with me.  Did they have to pay for it?  Did they have to pay for it first, yes or no?  Did they have to pay for it, yes or no?  No, they paid for it with work.  Do you have to pay for living in where you live now?
Well, it's bought now.  I already paid for it.
Right.  And then where did you get the money to pay for it?
I used to work in corporate America.
Now I own my own business.  I rest my case.
What are you resting?

that you people try to act like black people way back then were just so awful, and you want to use that today in order to try to make white people feel guilty and get free stuff and feel like victims.  Let me ask, what does it feel like to be a male and whining and blaming just like the females?  What does that feel like?
Well, let me speak for a second.  Don't cut me off, please.

Answer that question.  If you don't answer that question, I'm going to cut you off.  What does it feel like as a male to be whining and blaming and acting like black females toward white people?  What does that feel like?
I don't know what that feels like because I don't whine about anything.
You just whine about slavery.

Let me just say this.  Don't cut me off.  It seems like if someone knows their history about what white folks did in this country and how they became in power and what happened with the blacks being enslaved, you say we're whining.
Now you're whining.
Hold on.  Knowing my history.
You're whining now.
I'm saying so knowing my history means I'm whining?

Yes.  It's not your history.  That's not your history.  Okay, let's bring that down.  Oh, black people, guys.  I'm sorry, white folks.  I'll get to y'all in a minute.  So it's not your history.  Let me ask you, Thomas, were you ever enslaved?  So how was that your history?
Because I'm a descendant of that.
No, you're not.  Can I say something?  No, you are not enslaved, so it's not your history.
No, I said descendant of those people.
Why do you people all identify with all black people?
Jesus Christ.
I don't know why you're calling his name.  You don't identify with him.
Yeah, I identify with that black Messiah.  I sure do.
See there?  That's what it's like.  This is why you're blind and can't see.
Okay, you said you were raised on a plantation.  Do you know where plantations come from?  Why they have plantations?
Yeah.
From slaves, right?
No, they bought the land.  The white people bought the land and developed it into a plantation.  I know black people who own plantations right now in Alabama.
Right now, I'm not saying now.  I'm saying our ancestors.
Is there anything wrong with black people owning plantations?  Is there anything wrong with black people owning plantations?
At this point, no, but back then they were made for slavery.

But how about the blacks who owned plantations back then?  Were they wrong then?  I don't know any.  You don't know any whites either.  You don't know any whites who had plantations.  It's not your history, Thomas.  Stop being crazy.
Can I say American history?
It's not your history.  It's not American history.  It's old people history.  It's not your history.  Stop identifying with it.  Are you a Christian?
I was raised as one.
Are you a Christian?  Not now, sir.  I didn't think so.
Sir, if I was, would that make me better?
Yes, you would be a better person if you were a Christian.  Because you're not, you're not a better person.
Satan is my daddy.

Satan is your daddy.  I heard you say that to that caller.  Say to anybody that identified with someone else's history, Satan is their daddy because you are an individual.  You are not everybody.  You're not everybody.  You're not every black.  You're you.  It's just crazy.  It's insane.  Thank you, Thomas.
You and I are Americans.  American history isn't our history.  No.  I'm an American.
So what?
American history isn't our history.
No, it's the folks who made it then, and now you keep it going if you had any sense.  Oh, wow.
You just see things totally different than I do, but that's all.
I know.  That's why you're suffering.
I'm not suffering.
Yes, you are.  You're suffering.  How?  In every way.  Thank you, Thomas.
Can I ask you the biblical question?  Yes.
Are you blessed or cursed?  Totally blessed.  In what way?

I'm healthy.  I've never been to prison.  Don't have a criminal record.  I'm not on drugs or alcohol.  I've been married for 26 years to the same woman.  I have two beautiful children.  One finished college.  One is getting ready to go on a basketball scholarship.  We own our own businesses, and we are living the American dream.  Yeah, there's a lot of white folks around me, but my money is green, just like theirs.
Amazing.  Some don't.
I speak to them.
Do you think blacks should get more reparations?
Well, Jews, Japanese, they get reparations, but for some reason with us, they don't want to give us reparations.
I thought you were blessed.  If you were blessed, why do you need reparations?  I didn't say I needed it.
I didn't say I needed it.
You did.  You said, if we want reparation, why shouldn't we get reparation?
If there are blacks who need it, give it to them.
Would a blessed man be talking about our blacks?
I'm saying if you give it to Jews and Japanese people, why can't they give it to black folks?
Would a blessed man be comparing himself to others?
Well, yeah, I'm no different than anybody else.
So you're not blessed then?  So you're not blessed?
My economic situation is a little different.
Amazing.  Thomas, thank you, buddy.  Thank you.  Thanks.  All right.
Amazing.
Absolutely amazing.
